awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Eye Tracking System
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal #:	12-29108
PI(s):		Holland-Minkley, Amanda
Institution:	Washington and Jefferson College
Title:  		MRI/Acq.: Acquisition of Eye Tracking System
Project Proposed:
This project from an undergraduate-serving institution, acquiring an Eye Tracking system, aims to add quantitative measures of changes in problem-solving techniques to more traditional outcomes-based assessments of student learning. The eye tracking system enables pursuing further work and greater quantitative analysis in design and usability research focused on issues such as the effect of the interface design of security-focused software on the secure behaviors and awareness of security features of the software users.
Current work at the institution focuses on the particular application of these methods in an introductory programming course. The Information Technology Leadership (ITL) faculty have broaden their research to encompass more mobile computing that has contributed in developing a collaboration with Biology faculty. In turn, this collaboration has given rise to a mobile application used when collecting ecological data in the field. A beta version, now under assessment, has been created and deployed where the eye tracking methods will be used to confirm that mobile technologies enable not only more accurate data collection, but better learning and retention on the part of the student researchers in the field.
Broader Impacts: 
This solely undergraduate institution core mission focuses on research involving significant undergraduate collaboration. In particular, the ITL Department is committed to enabling its majors to take part in significant research projects that allow them to act as true collaborators and not simply as coders or lab technicians. Thus, with an existing history of engaging undergraduates in design and usability research, a modern eye tracking system will strengthen the program making it accessible to more students. The system will play a role in classroom activities, labs, and independent projects. Students should gain fluency with the tool and with appropriate methods for using it in regular coursework. A service management course will be required for all seniors to partner with local non-profits to provide technical consulting or development. The system provides a platform for continued interdisciplinary research, including ongoing work in Biology and potential projects that involve Political Science, Gender and Women?s Studies, Sociology, and Psychology.

por.por_cntn:
This project has enabled the Computing & Information Studies Department at Washington & Jefferson College to acquire a Tobii X60 eye tracking system intended for use in undergraduate courses as well as for research collaboration within the department, with our students, and with colleagues across the College. This equipment permits researchers to track and record where a user is looking when viewing a computer screen or mobile device.

We have an strong existing departmental expertise in software, web, and device design. This equipment is commonly used in those disciplines to assess products. Having this equipment available for student use exposes them to the modern technologies used in the workplace. Our department is also strongly committed to interdisciplinary computing coursework and research. The purchased equipment supports this sort of interdisciplinary work as it is also frequently used in other disciplines, most prominently the social sciences. To date, we have been able to use the equipment effectively in an interdisciplinary collaboration involving undergraduates from both Computing & Information Studies and Sociology.

To support the impact of this equipment beyond just our department, we have developed a course appropriate for non-majors that satisfies our College's general education science requirement. In this course, students learn to use the eye tracking system to pursue their own research projects. This course helps expose students from any department to advanced technology, contributing to their overall technology skills development. Students are encouraged to develop projects drawing on content from their majors, leading to the wide range of projects described below. In this way, students are able to see the contributions of science and technology to a wide range of problems. The content and approach of this course is sufficiently novel that the instructor has been able to publish a paper on its pedagogy, structure, and outcomes. The instructor has also presented that work at a conference to disseminate information about this approach to teaching computing and scientific thinking to instructors at other schools.

To date, students from both within and outside the Computing & Information Studies major have pursued a wide range of projects using this equipment, either in the context of a course or through indepedent, advanced research. This has included: testing principles of effective marketing by measuring attention to images theorized to drive engagement, investigating gender differences in how video content is viewed, measuring the effect of photo manipulation on image perception, exploring how patterns in how individuals perceive faces of different races apply when viewing mixed-race faces, and developing techologies to use eye-tracking data from a user viewing an image to later indentify that user if they view that image again in a different context. Two students have been able to present the results of their research at a research conference.
